entry.title: Audio output default device supports: setPreferredSinkId
entry.content:
There were requests for an audio output device API capable of setting the default audio output device for the entire web application, including the top frame and same/cross-origin subframes. The current and methods only impact the calling frame.

Request for WebKit Position on Audio output default device support.

entry.title: The `interesttarget` attribute
entry.content:
WebKittens

@annevk, @nt1m

Title of the proposal

The interesttarget attribute

URL to the spec

whatwg/html#11006

URL to the spec's repository

https://github.com/whatwg/html

Issue Tracker URL

No response

Explainer URL

https://open-ui.org/components/interest-invokers.explainer/

TAG Design Review URL

No response

Mozilla standards-positions issue URL

mozilla/standards-positions#1181

WebKit Bugzilla URL

No response

Radar URL

No response

Description

See also, whatwg/html#10309, which has reached Stage 1 of the WHATWG.

This is closely related to both the popover=hint feature, the commandfor attribute, and the anchor positioning API. This API (interesttarget) is the final piece needed in order to unlock the ability to declaratively build tooltips, hovercards, and menus that are triggered by mouse-hover or keyboard/touchscreen.

I am requesting standards positions early in the process, in the hopes of getting valuable technical input on the shape of this API. The current explainer has the latest plan, but that's evolving rapidly. While there is a very draft spec PR, it doesn't yet contain all of the details, so the explainer should be the source of truth for now. Your input is appreciated now, as critical decisions are being made.

If you'd like to try out a prototype implementation, Chrome Canary with "Experimental Web Platform Features" enabled can be used with this quick demo: https://jsbin.com/cosusih/edit?html,output. Note that touchscreen behaviors have not yet been implemented, and details are again changing rapidly.

entry.title: Partitioning cross-site top-level navigations in the HTTP cache
entry.content:
WebKittens

@annevk

Title of the proposal

Partitioning cross-site top-level navigations in the HTTP cache

URL to the spec

https://fetch.spec.whatwg.org/#http-cache-partitions

URL to the spec's repository

https://github.com/whatwg/fetch

Issue Tracker URL

No response

Explainer URL

No response

TAG Design Review URL

No response

Mozilla standards-positions issue URL

mozilla/standards-positions#1177

WebKit Bugzilla URL

No response

Radar URL

No response

Description

Chrome is planning to ship an update to its HTTP cache keying scheme that will include an “is-cross-site-top-level-navigation” boolean to mitigate cross-site leak attacks involving top-level navigations. Specifically, this will prevent cross-site attacks in which an attacker can initiate a top-level navigation to a given page and then navigate to a resource known to be loaded by the page in order to infer sensitive information via load timing. This change also improves privacy by preventing a malicious site from using navigations to infer whether a user has visited a given site previously. More information on this attack can be found at: https://xsleaks.dev/docs/attacks/navigations/#partitioned-http-cache-bypass

From a standards perspective, the spec calls for partitioning the HTTP cache by at least top-level site, but partitioning beyond that is implementation-defined. The relevant parts of the spec are:

  • https://fetch.spec.whatwg.org/#determine-the-network-partition-key
  • https://fetch.spec.whatwg.org/#http-cache-partitions

IIUC, all browsers do partition by top-level site [1][2], but there hasn't been much recent progress on standardizing beyond that. Some existing differences I'm aware of:

  • Chrome also partitions by frame site and an "is-subframe-navigation" boolean
  • Firefox also partitions using an "is-cross-origin-fetch" boolean [3]

I've left a comment about this in whatwg/fetch#1035 (comment), but opening this as well to get a formal standards position. Thanks!

[1] https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Privacy/State_Partitioning#network_partitioning
[2] https://webkit.org/tracking-prevention/#partitioned-third-party-http-cache
[3] https://hg.mozilla.org/mozilla-central/rev/94ed4d6361b3

entry.title: Incremental Font Transfer
entry.content:
WebKittens

@annevk

Title of the proposal

Incremental Font Transfer

URL to the spec

https://w3c.github.io/IFT/Overview.html

URL to the spec's repository

https://github.com/w3c/IFT

Issue Tracker URL

https://github.com/w3c/IFT/issues

Explainer URL

https://github.com/w3c/IFT/blob/main/IFT-Explainer.md

TAG Design Review URL

(not yet)

Mozilla standards-positions issue URL

mozilla/standards-positions#872

WebKit Bugzilla URL

No response

Radar URL

No response

Description

IFT is a modified OpenType font which contains enough to render a starting subset of (code points, font features, variation axes) plus a table of links to download patches on demand. The patches expand the font as needed to render more characters, more variation axes, etc.

As static files (one base font plus a bunch of patches), these are easy to host and fit with modern CDN.

Unlike static subsetting (e.g. google fonts) IFT do not break shaping for complex writing systems like Arabic and Indic languages.

IFT is expected to make webfonts practical for the first time for languages like Chinese and Japanese, where download size prohibited realistic use until now.

entry.title: H26x Codec support updates for MediaRecorder
entry.content:
WebKittens

@youennf

Title of the proposal

H26x Codec support updates for MediaRecorder

URL to the spec

https://www.w3.org/TR/mediastream-recording/

URL to the spec's repository

No response

Issue Tracker URL

No response

Explainer URL

https://docs.google.com/document/d/1YijhqWaeI118xqZV6Fd-UtqWpGDc-vFfFS6Dg4JEEqc/edit?tab=t.0#heading=h.66h4vpm7o59u

TAG Design Review URL

No response

Mozilla standards-positions issue URL

mozilla/standards-positions#1174

WebKit Bugzilla URL

No response

Radar URL

No response

Description

Chromium's MediaRecorder API now supports HEVC encoding, introducing the hvc1.* codec string, and adds new codec strings (hev1.* and avc3.*) supporting variable resolution video in MP4.

Support for HEVC platform encoding was added in WebCodecs in Chromium M130. As a follow-up, support has been added to the MediaRecorder API in Chromium. The API now supports both MP4 and Matroska muxer types with different HEVC and H.264 mime type specifications. HEVC encoding is only supported if the user's device and operating system provide the necessary capabilities.

Work on the Chromium side is being tracked here.

entry.title: require-sri-for CSP directive
entry.content:
WebKittens

@annevk

Title of the proposal

require-sri-for CSP directive

URL to the spec

w3c/webappsec-subresource-integrity#129

URL to the spec's repository

No response

Issue Tracker URL

No response

Explainer URL

No response

TAG Design Review URL

w3ctag/design-reviews#1048

Mozilla standards-positions issue URL

No response

WebKit Bugzilla URL

No response

Radar URL

No response

Description

Subresource-Integrity (SRI) enables developers to make sure the assets they intend to load are indeed the assets they are loading. But there's no current way for developers to be sure that all of their scripts are validated using SRI.

The require-sri-for CSP directive gives developers the ability to assert that every resource of a given type needs to be integrity checked. If a resource of that type is attempted to be loaded without integrity metadata, that attempt will fail and trigger a CSP violation report.

entry.title: HTML `<portal>` element
entry.content:
WebKittens

Google: @jeremyroman @lucasgadani (Chromium Portals)
Apple: @marcoscaceres @zachernuk (Immersive Web, 3D <model> element)

Title of the proposal

Portals

URL to the spec

https://wicg.github.io/portals/

URL to the spec's repository

https://github.com/WICG/portals

Issue Tracker URL

https://github.com/WICG/portals/issues

Explainer URL

https://web.dev/articles/hands-on-portals

TAG Design Review URL

No response

Mozilla standards-positions issue URL

mozilla/standards-positions#157

WebKit Bugzilla URL

No response

Radar URL

No response

Description

This feature would be super futurizing for the metaverse. Many people are trying hard to build the metaverse, and many people don't even know they need it yet, but the limiting factor is that only a few key technologies (Chrome, Safari, Firefox, and a few other browsers) have the true power to implement the features the metaverse needs in a standardized way that many people can access. Anything else less then a browser is just a convention that some people might follow and that other people might try to supplant. However, standards in browsers become cemented APIs that force the majority of Earth to coalesce on one way of doing things, which is what we need for a concept such as a true metaverse.

Imagine websites (2D or 3D), and you can transition to other websites (2D or 3D). As a standard, this would make it possible to traverse worlds in 3D space in a shared way, relying on decentralized domain names for representing worlds.

Now imagine, for example, with optional communication between the websites (i.e. 3D worlds), the camera position of one world can be aligned with that of the nested world (i.e. real "portals" or doorways to other worlds).

I'm working on https://lume.io, which provides 3D custom HTML elements, and these are the sorts of things I envision being openly standardized in the future.

This is all possible right now, but it would be non-standard. For example, I could perhaps wire up some iframes and invent a way to communicate across the domains, share camera data, and make the "jump" across worlds happen.

However it would be very hacky to avoid a very bad UX. For one, there would necessarily need to be an infinite stack of iframes, otherwise any time one wished to traverse into a world there would need to be a full page reload to cause the nested iframe to become the top iframe so that it can take over the URL in the address bar, and that would be a really bad user experience. To avoid these full page reloads, we'd need to create a convention across coordinated websites so that they can support a URL format that can store the nested set of iframe domains in order to afford sub-navigation in each iframe, and this would get extremely complicated.

Native portals solve all the issues. As soon as we enter a portal, it becomes the top-level page, and controls the address bar, just as if we visited that website in the first place.

Portals would help us progress towards a true metaverse in a much more modern and standard way by natively handling worlds in worlds in worlds in worlds. URL address bar hacks would not be necessary, for example, as the browser would instead integrate natively into the browser history, there'd be no need to track a stack of iframes using APIs that are limited compared to the browser's own native APIs, etc.

Imagine this

  • Imagine you're walking around a 3D world that looks like minecraft (for sake of example)
  • you walk into a house
  • in that house is a computer, or simply a floating panel, with a website in it, for example an online store.
  • you could interact with the website, or you could enter it.
  • you enter the website, which happens to be 2D, so now this 2D website takes up your window.
  • you are exploring products on the 2D website.
  • in the 2D website, you discover a portal to a 3D minigame that sells the product, so you click enter it.
  • the view zooms in and you are now inside the 3D game for the product.
  • you hit the back button, and you're back in the 2D store
  • you bookmark the product for later, as currently you already spent all your money on stuff
  • you hit the back button again and you get back into the minecraft-like world inside the home where you previously were
  • You might be doing all this on a regular monitor, or you might be doing all this in a VR headset (f.e. Quest Browser or VisionOS Safari).

THIS. Is the future.

entry.title: Fire error event instead of throwing exception for CSP blocked worker constructor
entry.content:
WebKittens

No response

Title of the proposal

Fire error event instead of throwing exception for CSP blocked worker constructor

URL to the spec

https://www.w3.org/TR/CSP3/#fetch-integration

URL to the spec's repository

No response

Issue Tracker URL

No response

Explainer URL

No response

TAG Design Review URL

No response

Mozilla standards-positions issue URL

No response

WebKit Bugzilla URL

No response

Radar URL

No response

Description

When blocked by Content Security Policy, Safari and Chromium currently throws SecurityError from constructor when new Worker(url) and new SharedWorker(url) is run. However, spec requires CSP to be checked as part of fetch which happens asynchronously. So the correct behavior should be not throw exception in Worker and SharedWorker constructor, but instead fire error event, which Firefox is currently doing.

There are WPT tests that are testing the behavior of CSP blocked worker. However the test code currently wrongly expects the SecurityError exception. There is a TODO comment in the test code linking to https://crbug.com/663298 indicating that the tests should be updated. See https://github.com/web-platform-tests/wpt/blob/109d4a64f757cc6689e7050f1cea59a2c1823eca/content-security-policy/support/testharness-helper.js#L100-L104 and https://github.com/web-platform-tests/wpt/blob/109d4a64f757cc6689e7050f1cea59a2c1823eca/content-security-policy/support/testharness-helper.js#L119-L123. The tests are https://wpt.fyi/results/content-security-policy/worker-src/dedicated-worker-src-child-fallback-blocked.sub.html?label=experimental&label=master&aligned and
https://wpt.fyi/results/content-security-policy/worker-src/shared-worker-src-child-fallback-blocked.sub.html?label=experimental&label=master&aligned.

We intent to change Chromium's behavior to be aligned with the spec and update the test code.

entry.title: Allowing SameSite=None Cookies in First-Party Sandboxed Contexts
entry.content:
WebKittens

@annevk

Title of the proposal

Allowing SameSite=None Cookies in First-Party Sandboxed Contexts

URL to the spec

whatwg/html#10915

URL to the spec's repository

https://github.com/whatwg/html

Issue Tracker URL

No response

Explainer URL

https://github.com/explainers-by-googlers/csp-sandbox-allow-same-site-none-cookies

TAG Design Review URL

w3ctag/design-reviews#1004

Mozilla standards-positions issue URL

mozilla/standards-positions#1165

WebKit Bugzilla URL

No response

Radar URL

No response

Description

When third-party cookies (3PC) are blocked by Chrome and Firefox, contexts with the Content-Security-Policy: sandbox header or <iframe> sandbox attribute are no longer able to use SameSite=None cookies. The frame must include the allow-same-origin value to use cookies, which relaxes many security protections including the opaque origin.

We want to restore existing behavior and enable a frame to signal the browser to include SameSite=None cookies in first-party requests from sandboxed frames when 3PC restrictions are active with the allow-same-site-none-cookies value

entry.title: Navigation API: deferred commit
entry.content:
WebKittens

No response

Title of the proposal

Navigation API: deferred commit

URL to the spec

https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/nav-history-apis.html#dom-navigateevent-intercept

URL to the spec's repository

https://github.com/whatwg/html

Issue Tracker URL

https://github.com/whatwg/html

Explainer URL

https://github.com/WICG/navigation-api/blob/main/README.md#deferred-commit

TAG Design Review URL

w3ctag/design-reviews#1040

Mozilla standards-positions issue URL

No response

WebKit Bugzilla URL

No response

Radar URL

No response

Description

The current behavior of the navigation API updates the URL and the current history entry immediately when intercepting.
This has been a pain point for early adopters of the API.
This proposal is to make this behavior configurable, allowing the developer using the API to defer the commit behavior and call commit when ready.

entry.title: Permissions Policy reports for iframes
entry.content:
WebKittens

No response

Title of the proposal

Permissions Policy reports for iframes

URL to the spec

w3c/webappsec-permissions-policy#546

URL to the spec's repository

No response

Issue Tracker URL

No response

Explainer URL

No response

TAG Design Review URL

No response

Mozilla standards-positions issue URL

mozilla/standards-positions#1164

WebKit Bugzilla URL

No response

Radar URL

No response

Description

Permissions Policy violation reports for cross-origin iframes are only sent to the iframe's reporting endpoint and not to the embedder's reporting endpoint, because of the concern that it might leak sensitive information about a cross-origin iframe.
However, this makes it difficult for sites to enforce Permissions Policy because it can't learn about breakages in cross-origin iframes.

This feature introduces a new violation type called "Potential Permissions Policy violation", which will only look at existing Permissions Policy (including report-only policy) and the allow attribute set in iframes to detect the conflict between Permissions Policy enforced vs permissions being propagated to iframes. Since both Permissions Policy and allow attributes are set by the embedder, this feature does not leak any new information to the embedder.

However, Potential Permissions Policy violations will be sent when an iframe is loaded, and not when the iframe uses the prohibited feature, which is different from the normal Permissions Policy violations (hence the name "potential").

https://chromestatus.com/feature/5154241037205504

entry.title: CSS Overflow Navigation Controls
entry.content:
WebKittens

CSS Overflow 5: Scroll navigation controls

Description

There are a variety of problems being solved by carousels, which we believe could be provided by a small set of CSS features. Developers could then combine these CSS features to create the various designs. CSS-only component libraries could be built to further simplify this process.
